title: Tuesday, 21st March, 2017

PM11:06am

BE11:07am

Petrol's a lot of it, but not all of it. This isn't just imported input costs, though I guess there's a longer and much more turgid debate to be had about secondary effects of imported input costs.

11:08 am

11:08 am
BE11:08am

And house prices turning negative on London, if you want to go DPL as well.

PM11:09am

hehe -- i thought we were saving that for later

PM11:09am

alewis2005 -- journalists. Sunset industry etc

11:09 am
BE11:09am

It's lucky we have the divisive and polarising Brexit noise to distract ourselves, otherwise the electorate might be getting a bit uneasy.

BE11:10am

But that's getting ahead of the matter. Can we grab some grey on the CPI?

PM11:10am

Have some David Tinsley

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Exane

PM11:10am

UK headline inflation leapt past the Bank of England's 2.0% target in February. The headline rate printed at 2.3%, up from 1.8% in January.

Within the detail, food & non-alcoholic beverages and transport prices were major drivers of the increase. But recreation and culture prices also was a significant contributor to the upward movement.

Within the transport category, it was the rise in petrol prices that had the biggest impact. This year fuel prices rose by 1.2% between January and February, while a year ago fuel prices fell by 1.0%. The rise in food price inflation came across a range of products, including vegetables where poor growing conditions have been reported in southern Europe, impacting iceberg lettuces for one.

PM11:10am

The rise in inflation in recreation and culture is reported to be across a range of items. PCs, laptops and tablets showed a rise in prices compared to falls last year.

While some of the reasons for the pick-up in inflation today sound of a transitory nature - dollar oil prices have since fallen - it is notable that core inflation rose to 2.0%, from 1.6% previously. So the impression is that a portion of the increase is more reflective of the pass-through from previous exchange rate weakness into final consumer prices. Non-energy industrial goods inflation is now running at 0.8% y/y, compared to close to flat in previous months.

There are two possible narratives for the wider economy for this data. One is that higher inflation eats into real wage growth, slowing the economy. The other is that this higher inflation puts greater pressure on the Bank of England to tighten policy. For now the second narrative is in the ascendancy in the UK, in part reflecting the Bank of England's discussions at the February meeting. So sterling is benefiting from this data this morning and short-sterling is dropping. For now this looks like the path of least resistance. But it can be tested in coming weeks if the activity data takes a marked downward lurch.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Kallum Pickering of Berenberg as well, if you like.

BE11:11am

The price of Brexit: Even before Brexit creates any barriers to trade – at least two years away – UK households are already forking out more for German cars, Italian cheese and French wine. Thanks to the 13% fall in trade-weighted sterling since the Brexit vote (down 12% versus the euro), prices of imported goods are rising sharply. In February, headline inflation (CPI) hit its highest rate – 2.3% yoy - since September 2013, increasing from 1.8% in January, and beating expectations of 2.1%. Linked to the weak currency, factory input costs rose by 19.1% yoy in February. Meanwhile, underlying inflationary pressures continue to build amid limited spare capacity, tight labour market conditions and continued strong demand at home and abroad. Core inflation, which excludes the volatile food and energy components, rose to 2.0% in February from 1.6% in January. CPIH (CPI inc. owner occupiers’ housing costs) - the ONS’s preferred inflation series - was 2.3% in February, up from 1.9% in January. Note: The Chancellor could alter the BoE’s official target to CPIH later in the year. The BoE currently targets CPI.

BE11:11am

How much could rising inflation hurt consumption? We expect headline inflation to peak at 3.0% in Q3 2017 before easing a little thereafter, but remaining above the BoE’s 2% target through 2018. The sharp rise in inflation will squeeze household incomes in 2017 and 2018 even as tight labour market conditions will likely lead to a modest rise in nominal wage growth from current rates of around 2.5% yoy (3M average). Critically, we do not expect the sizeable real income squeeze to fully pass through into real consumption in the coming years. Instead, we look for only a modest easing of real consumption growth; from 3.0% in 2016, to 2.3% in 2017 and 1.9% in 2018. Household balance sheets have strengthened since the Lehman-crisis; debt-to-income is lower, household wealth has risen, and thanks to low oil prices, households have enjoyed three years of solid real wage gains. Feeling confident after seven years of economic growth, the UK consumer started to gear up again last year. By increasing borrowing and saving less to target a desired level of consumption, we expect households to smooth spending over the medium-term as rising inflation squeezes real incomes.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

BoE’s tolerance for rising inflation could be tested soon: Remember the key guidance in the BoE’s March Monetary Policy Committee meeting minutes, that for ‘some’ committee members it would ‘take very little further upside news on the prospects for activity or inflation to consider that a more immediate reduction in policy support might be warranted’. That guidance came in addition to Kristen Forbes, a known hawk, voting for an immediate 25bps rate hike in the bank rate. With inflation set to rise further over the course of this year, today’s data is rather ‘big’ upside news. As we have repeatedly argued alongside our above consensus projections for real GDP growth since the Brexit vote (2.0% and 1.7% in 2017 and 2018 versus Bloomberg consensus of 1.6% and 1.3%, respectively), there is a clear case for tighter monetary policy in the UK. In a non-Brexit scenario, the BoE would have probably hiked by now. Worryingly for the BoE, inflation expectations are rising well above the 2% target – Chart 2. By pushing up pricing and wage decisions, rising inflation expectations reduce the likelihood that inflation will fall back to the target after the FX effects have passed – increasing the need for action.

BE11:12am

As our base case, we look for a 25bp first rate hike in Q2 2018, with a 30% chance the BoE raises the bank rate earlier. After today’s data release, risks to that call are skewed towards the BoE hiking sooner rather than later. ‎ After the first hike, the BoE will likely continue to proceed with extra caution, with small and infrequent rate hikes signalled far in advance, and with a strong bias toward remaining in neutral as and when risks to growth surface.

BE11:12am

(@Soundbuy: Yes. The Express.)

11:12 am
undefined
BE11:12am

Moving on to corporate, such as it is ..........

BE11:13am

...... Berendsen mentioned. Which is a Barclays downgrade.

11:13 am
Berendsen PLC (BRSN:LSE): Last: 813.50, down 44.5 (-5.19%), High: 830.00, Low: 794.50, Volume: 814.43k
BE11:13am

Argument is that that, while management might fix things, they also might not.

BE11:14am

Less than 18 months on from a strategic review that reported a “well invested” business with “strong foundations” and committed to free cash conversion of 75-90% and a double-digit ROIC, BRSN has reported significant operational issues in the UK and a sizeable increase in capex which decimates the cash conversion target and sees ROIC back into single figures for at least the next few years, in our view. While we do not dispute the need for a step-up in capex to address previous underinvestment, we are (a) slightly alarmed by the initial assessment of the situation in November 2015 and (b) slightly puzzled by the additional growth capex plans – has the view of end markets changed so much since the strategic review in November 2015 that a £150m+ increase in capex is merited for a business which has historically grown only slightly ahead of GDP? Undertaking a major capex programme is a challenge for any business but it looks even trickier to execute while churning c40% of the UK managers (c180 people leaving, 150 new hires planned), embarking on a major re-training exercise for existing employees and putting in place a series of new systems. Based on our revised forecasts, BRSN trades on a CY2018E PE of 14.5x, broadly in line with the five-year average 12m forward PE of 14.7x, which we view as unjustified given our view of the earnings and cash profile over the next three years. With execution risk at elevated levels and questions over the merits of a meaningful step-up in growth capex, we move to Underweight (previously Equal Weight) and lower our PT to 700p (previously 911p).

11:14 am
BE11:15am

FY17F and FY18F EPS cut by 13%, placing us 4% and 5% below consensus respectively (using Thomson Reuters consensus for those forecasts which have been updated since the results). Based on our revised forecasts, we expect BRSN to deliver an FY19F EPS of 63.1p, the same level of EPS as it delivered in FY16A, ie three years to get back to FY16 profits. Alongside this earnings profile, we see leverage at 1.6x at the end of FY19F vs 1.2x at Dec-16A, reflecting the impact of increased capex alongside management’s commitment to continuing to grow the dividend.

BE11:15am

Which doesn't need any further explanation really.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

BE11:21am

BE11:22am

11:22 am

BE11:23am

More newsworthy, arguably, is the Reuters story about four Dutch provincial governments opposing a deal it due to concerns related to job losses

PM11:23am

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Gelderland, Overijssel, Groningen and Zuid Holland -- yes, I had to cut and paste those names -- publish a joint statement saying the takeover "would put 5,000 jobs at risk in the provinces”

BE11:24am

Which feels a bit low, frankly.

BE11:24am

On the animal spirit side of the argument, there was a survey out of Bernstein at the end of last week saying shareholders like money.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

80% of respondents want Akzo to engage with PPG. They think €95 is a fair value for the company (+27% upside from current price of €75); however, only ~40% expect an agreed deal despite only moderate concerns (only 30% chance) of anti-trust regulators blocking (Exhibits 1-4). (This is quite consistent with the current share price, which implies about 32% chance of a closed deal assuming a 10% spread.) Divestures could total about $2bn (we wrote $2.3bn), and costs synergies about $600m (same as our estimate)

BE11:25am

Absent a PPG deal, investors expect Akzo shares to trade ~€70/share (about 7% downside), similar to our estimate of €71. The top priority for investors is the separation of Spec Chem and expect about €9bn EV (similar to our €8.5bn). Surprisingly, the second most important priority is redoubling efforts on costs rather than growth. We had expected "growth" to be high on the list, but it was hardly mentioned. Akzo still has the potential to narrow the margin gap vs. peers, which was about 440bps vs. PPG in 2016, in part through further headcount and cost reductions.

BE11:26am

Opinion more divided with regards a strategy.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

A few favored a bid for Axalta, while a few others cautioned against it. Several favored bolt-ons and the return of cash to shareholders. Notably the comments were nowhere near as scathing as those in our Syngenta survey following the rejection of Monsanto's bid.

BE11:26am

Bernstein's odds are .............

BE11:27am

50% chance of a €93 bid, 40% chance of a Spec Chem spinoff (valuing Akzo at €73), and 10% for the status quo at €64.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We, however, don't know.

11:28 am

PM11:29am

11:29 am
PM11:29am

Didn't Deutsche have their one last week?

PM11:29am

yes they did

PM11:29am

I have the key takeaways!

11:29 am
PM11:29am

Key takeaways from the conference:
 Mortgage lending: asset pricing continues to fall (now 0.99% for 60% LTV 2-yr fix) with the market for new business remaining extremely competitive. Lenders are increasingly using brokers (back to pre-crisis levels), though not differentiating just on price (also on speed and ease of broker platform). Remortgaging is expected to grow further if rates rise (and conversely decrease if house prices fall). RWA inflation is in train (e.g. at RBS) but mortgages are still high-RoTE product, with most banks very keen to grow.

PM11:30am

Buy to let: lending volumes are expected to be lower in 2017 than 2016, driven by tax and affordability changes, but not dramatically so. Remortgaging remains c.2/3 of new lending, which should provide some support. Rule changes are likely to drive an increased divergence between lenders serving professional & amateur BTL borrowers. Demand for 5-year fixed rate loans has increased, due to customer desire to fix (and likely PRA rule changes). Proposals which reduce the gap between standardised (35%) and IRB risk weights could prove positive for challenger banks.

PM11:30am

Unsecured lending: some banks have expressed concern over record-low personal loan unsecured rates on offer (now 2.9% for up to £20k), given through-the-cycle loan losses of 3-4%. But the advertised ‘representative APR’ is a somewhat misleading indicator, as 49% of customers are ‘risk priced’ at higher rates (effective avg. new rate is actually 6.8%). Meanwhile, markets for zero balance transfer credit cards and car finance remain buoyant. Meanwhile impairments are benign: no bank mentioned any deterioration in asset quality, whilst VISA spending data for 2017 has been robust so far.

Welcome to Markets Live

11:34 am
BE11:35am

The results follow on from the strong trading update issued on 24th January, where management guided to the full year performance being materially ahead of current market expectations. Therefore, we upgraded our financial expectations for FY2016 onwards, increasing our EPS estimate for the year by 11%, which also fed through to a 9% increase for FY2017F. The trading statement provided specific guidance on the FY2016 revenue performance, so the focus in the results today was on profitability and the outlook for the business.

PM11:35am

Certainly bemused us, this one

PM11:35am

But it's hit all forecasts to date

11:35 am

BE11:35am

BE11:36am

BE11:37am

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Ive got to confess I've begun buying Fever-tree sometimes.

PM11:38am

The local sainsburys doesnt stock little cans of tonic -- and I hate the large plastic Schweppes bottles, that go flat almost immediately they are open

BE11:38am

That's the issue, in part. There's not much competition.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And the valuation hinges on it repeating the "sole supplier" trick in Europe and the US ...........

BE11:38am

........ which rather ignores that companies doing 73% revenue growth and a 55% gross margin will tend to attract a few competitors.

BE11:39am

Britvic rejigged its bottles at the end of last year. http://www.britvic...ws/2016/03-10-2016

11:40 am
BE11:40am

There's also some very Fever-Tree-ish heritage brand thing being advertised on the Tube right now, though I wasn't paying enough attention to note its name.

BE11:40am

What are the barriers to entry here? The pub and bar wholesalers?

BE11:41am

Well, there's a reason the beer tie existed. That particular barrier to entry can be eroded quite quickly with predatory discounting.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

And in the growth markets -- as in, Europe and the US -- the "Schweppes shambles" thing isn't as easily exploitable, partly because Schweppes (which is a slew of licencing agreements rather than a company) has improved but mostly because competitors have several years to have noticed the opportunity.

BE11:43am

Ah, nuts. Back to Shore.

BE11:43am

Fever-Tree operates an outsourced model to provide scalability and flexibility, and we note its core partner in the UK has invested in its site in 2016 to double its capacity from 2017 onwards. The group also has a second UK bottler for contingency purposes as well as a Netherlands-based canner, and it continues to bottle locally in Germany with the reusable bottles required in that market. Therefore, we see the business as well positioned in terms of its supply capability in respect of capacity, flexibility and contingency.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Management continues to be innovative and has a strong focus on new product development. The launch of the 150ml can in 2015 has been a notable success, which has since seen its range extended into Elderflower and Mediterranean Tonic Water in 2016 with further extensions to come in 2017. We also highlight the launch of pink Aromatic Tonic Water in 2016 in the UK and a market-specific Clementine Tonic Water in Belgium. There was also the launch of a new embossed glass bottle in H2 2016 to further underpin the premium credentials of the Fever-Tree brand. We also note management’s evolving strategy to look to target mixers for dark spirits, which in the premium global market have a 60% market share compared with 6% for premium gin. New products to target this opportunity are to be launched in FY2017.

PM11:43am

This is all quite fascinating

BE11:44am

Elderflower and Mediterranean Tonic Water! I'm fascinated.

11:44 am

PM11:44am

11:44 am
PM11:44am

In 2009 the state of Maine in the United States banned the sale of Fentimans Victorian Lemonade to anyone aged under 21 after reclassifying it as an "Imitation Liquor". The ban was introduced after a schoolboy in the small town of Houlton, Maine noticed the lemonade's label stated it contained "up to 0.5% alcohol" and showed his high school principal. They in turn contacted the local police who went to the State's liquor licensing officials and Maine's attorney general's office

PM11:45am

Fentimans responded to the ban with a statement telling any concerned citizens of Houlton and law enforcement officers and officials to steer clear of the company's other naturally-fermented botanical soft drinks

PM11:45am

Brilliant publicity

Sweden’s financial authorities are investigating how fraudsters issued a forged press release on behalf of a Swedish biometrics company that claimed it had been acquired by Samsung Electronics for $650m, sending the shares soaring by 50 per cent.

Fingerprint Cards, which develops biometric technology to enhance the security of mobile devices, made the embarrassing discovery on Friday morning that an unauthorised press release had been distributed in its name and posted to its website.

PM11:51am

hehehe

BE11:51am

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Fingerprint Cards warned for Q1 and decided to refrain from giving guidance for 2017 (previously revenue SEK7,500-9,500m and operating margin greater than 35%). Management expects a revenue y-o-y decline of more than 50% for Q1 (consensus -17% y-o-y). The company points out that high inventory levels throughout the supply chain continue to affect shipment volumes and revenues in Q1 and Q2. Given the magnitude of the decline and despite the fact that FPC is mainly exposed to Chinese OEMs, we believe market share loss and inventory management are likely.

BE11:52am

As a result of the weak start to the year, FPC announced that it will withdraw its previously proposed dividend for 2016 (2 SEK per share), but will continue to innovate and strengthen the IP portfolio (we had assumed this would be cut to 0 but in '18).

BE11:52am

It is hard to gauge the impact of consensus (as there is no guidance in 2017) but we would expect consensus to decrease by at least 30%. Given the trend, we would expect EBIT margin to be low double-digit in Q1).

11:52 am
BE11:52am

They put their sell rating under review.

PM11:53am

What could they move to? Avoid?

BE11:54am

I guess, when you don't have any forecasts whatsoever for the current year, you can't make a recommendation. And that's what Fingerprint's given to us this morning.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

There's a possible line here about giving us the Finger, but to use it seems cheap and unnecessary.

undefined
BE11:55am

So, there's DPL.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Mentioned at the open that greater London house prices are about to go negative having fallen in six of the past 12 months.

BE11:56am

ONS data is 0.8% month-on-month and 6.2% year-on-year nationally.

PM11:56am

Brexit jitters really have arrived

11:56 am
BE11:56am

For one market, to be fair.

BE11:57am

(@alewis2005: I don't know. I'd guess zone 2, but Google might be more relevant than my prejudices.)

BE11:58am

Have Howard Archer to summarise, and save me typing.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

· The house price index produced by the Office for National Statistics showed house prices rising 0.8% in January. This caused the annual rate of increase to rise back up to 6.2% in January from 5.7% in December and a 14-month low of 5.3% in November.
· It needs to be borne in mind that the ONS’ measure of house price inflation lags many of the other measures as it is based on mortgage completions. Furthermore, house data for February from both the Nationwide and the Halifax showed slowing annual house price inflation.
· Despite the solid-looking January house price data from the ONS, we expect housing market activity and prices to come under increasing pressure over the coming months from deteriorating consumer fundamentals and weaker confidence.
· Consequently, we suspect that house price gains over 2017 will be no more than 3% - and it could very well be less than this.
· We expect the fundamentals for house buyers to progressively deteriorate during 2017 with consumers’ purchasing power weakening markedly and the labour market likely softening. Increasing economic uncertainty is also likely to weigh down on consumer confidence and willingness to engage in major transactions such as buying a house. Housing market activity and prices are also likely to be pressurized by stretched house prices to earnings ratios and tight checking of prospective mortgage borrowers by lenders
· However, the downside for house prices will be limited markedly by a shortage of houses for sale. Ongoing very low mortgage interest rates should also help the housing market.

BE11:58am

Now, I mention this in part because Morgan Stanley has an initiation of the housebuilders out this morning.

PM11:59am

Only now initiating coverage??

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Change of analyst, I think.

BE11:59am

We initiate on the 4 largest stocks, with Barratt and Taylor
Wimpey most preferred. Share prices are 3x geared to house
prices, but can perform even if prices stay flat, given healthy
RoEs and low P/Es. An upside case of mid-single digit house
price growth adds a further 15% to price targets.

BE12:00pm

Why look now? (1) UK housebuilder stocks have historically been about 3x geared into house price growth (6 months forward), and, as pure developers reliant on sales market liquidity, have suffered with other UK property stocks in the last 12 months. (2) As the London 'h alo' fades, investment in the broader UK housing market via housebuilders offers a liquid alternative to investment in UK REITs, which have a strong bias to London (where pricing and Brexit risk is higher) or to structural headwinds in other sub-segments such as retail.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Peak margins, but still healthy returns on offer. Housebuilders have enjoyed a period of huge earnings recovery, are delivering close-to-peak returns on capital and equity and paying out a peak level of earnings with prices backed by the tailwind of Help-to-Buy. But returns remained at this level for around a decade between 1997 and 2006, and, with the notable exception of London, the margin between house prices and development land is still high. As a result, we expect growth (in earnings and book value) to only slow modestly and only turn negative for London specialists such as Berkeley Group.

BE12:00pm

UK house prices benefiting from inflecting household leverage. We see support for UK house prices moving in line with nominal GDP growth over the long term given an ongoing undersupplied market. Our forecasts currently assume low single-digit growth in broader UK house price indices, even with central London house price growth likely to underperform. Nearer term, changes in household leverage (which has recently inflected upwards) and long-term interest rates, as well as Help-to-Buy, are other key drivers of change (see our detailed 30-year multifactor regression analysis). Key risks remain changing demographics, policy (macroprudential or housing-related).

BE12:01pm

Valuation: P/E or P/B? Historical cost (rather than mark-to-market) accounting and limited disclosure makes forecasting and valuation more opaque than for European property stocks, but our exhaustive analysis of key drivers suggests forward EPS growth is a key driver, even if forecasting success rates are remarkably and consistently low. We combine this with a return on capital approach to set price targets. We see total share price returns including dividends of 7-21%; Barratt is most preferred as the cheapest of the volume players with more room to improve margins and returns, and Berkeley least preferred given falling earnings in outer years and London exposure.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

68 pages of that.

Digitalisation: remains a key focus, particularly the larger incumbents who are seeking to improve customer experience as well as reduce costs. Barclays says the cost of serving a customer in branch is 7.5x that of a digital channel. We expect continued increase in digital delivery of services.
